Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these nail findings?
A classic diagnostic finding associated with psoriatic nails is nail pitting. Other characteristic features of nail psoriasis
include distal onycholysis (separation of the nail plate from the underlying nail bed) (
) and splinter hemorrhages, which represent the Auspitz sign (punctate bleeding) in the nail bed. In addition, some patients may display the oil-drop sign (
), which is characterized by a localized tan to brown discoloration of the nail.
In more severe forms of psoriatic involvement, there can be thickening and crumbling of the nails.
